{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's presentation is consistent with cryptorchidism, which is the absence of one or both testes from the scrotum. This is a common condition in preterm boys but most testes descend by the first year of life. If the testis is palpable, as in this case, the initial management is to monitor for spontaneous descent until the child is 6 months corrected gestational age. If the testis has not descended by this time, referral for orchiopexy is indicated to prevent complications such as infertility and testicular cancer. Chorionic gonadotropin therapy is not the first line of treatment. Exploratory laparoscopy is not necessary as the testis is palpable.
